abstract: When the taxpayers were the shareholders of major American banks, Washington had a say in how they were run. But now the White House has been left in the position of extending invitations, rather than exercising its clout.
snippet: When the taxpayers were the shareholders of major American banks, Washington had a say in how they were run. But now the White House has been left in the position of extending invitations, rather than exercising its clout.
lead_paragraph: Now that Citigroup has given back its bailout money — and Wells Fargo announced late on Monday that it would, too — whatever leverage Washington had over the financial services industry seems to be quickly eroding, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline.main: Putting Obama on Hold, in a Hint of Who’s Boss

abstract: How likely is the prospect of significant regulation of the banking industry from Washington? What leverage does the president really have? Room for Debate invited five luminaries to give their opinions.
snippet: How likely is the prospect of significant regulation of the banking industry from Washington? What leverage does the president really have? Room for Debate invited five luminaries to give their opinions.
lead_paragraph: As Citigroup and Wells Fargo became the last of the big Wall Street banks to announce they are repaying the funds from the Troubled Asset Relief Program, freeing themselves from government oversight on compensation and pay, what leverage does the president really have?

abstract: Wells Fargo and Citigroup plans to repay taxpayer funds will put the U.S. government on track to reduce its bailout investments in banks by more than 75 percent, while earning a healthy profit for the U.S., Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner said.
snippet: Wells Fargo and Citigroup plans to repay taxpayer funds will put the U.S. government on track to reduce its bailout investments in banks by more than 75 percent, while earning a healthy profit for the U.S., Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner said...
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo and Citigroup plans to repay taxpayer funds will put the U.S. government on track to reduce its bailout investments in banks by more than 75 percent, while earning a healthy profit for the U.S., Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner said on Monday, Reuters reported.

headline.main: TARP to Earn Healthy Profit For U.S., Geithner Says
